stem: A 44-year-old client is receiving a second unit of fresh frozen plasma (FFP). Two hours after the start, she develops sudden respiratory distress. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute respiratory failure post-plasma transfusion.
Background: History of Liver Cirrhosis and Coagulopathy.
Assessment: Client has severe dyspnea and is producing frothy, pink sputum.
Recommendation: Rule out TRALI vs. TACO.

tabs.title: Pulmonary & Hemodynamic Log
tabs.content:
AssessmentFindingSignificance
Blood Pressure88/52 mmHg (Low)Points to TRALI
Temperature101.8°F (Fever)Inflammatory response
Lung SoundsDiffuse bilateral cracklesNon-cardiogenic edema
CVP (if monitored)3 mmHg (Normal/Low)Not volume overload

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 88/52 mmHg, HR 128 bpm, RR 34 breaths/min, T 101.8°F (38.8°C). SpO2 74% on 6L NC.

actionOptions.text: Stop the transfusion and notify the provider and blood bank.
Provide aggressive respiratory support (O2 / CPAP / Intubation).
Lower the head of the bed to the flat position.

rationale.correct: This is TRALI (c2). The key differentiators from TACO are the HYPOTENSION (BP 88/52 mmHg) and the FEVER (101.8°F/38.8°C). TACO usually causes hypertension and no fever. TRALI is an inflammatory lung injury caused by donor antibodies. Priority actions are stopping the trigger (a1) and supporting ventilation (a2) since TRALI is the leading cause of transfusion-related death. Parameters include monitoring hemodynamics (p1) (Hypotension risk) and gas exchange (p2).
clinicalPearls: TRALI = Low BP + Fever. TACO = High BP + No Fever.
Diuretics (Furosemide) help TACO but can WORSEN TRALI by further lowering the blood pressure.
TRALI typically occurs within 6 hours of a transfusion.

questionTrap.trap: Giving Lasix for crackles in a transfusion patient with low blood pressure.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the BP is low, it's TRALI. Do not give diuretics! They need fluids and oxygen, not fluid removal.

mnemonic.title: TRALI vs TACO
mnemonic.expansion: TRALI = Terrible BP (Low). TACO = Tall BP (High).
